Changes Unknown when pulling **5eaca8b63819e06f936c52f10fde0bd7a75e7f52 on huafengw:fixtest** into ** on apache:master**.

I often hear people say they want the public methods ("core") at the top so that they are easily reachable -  I think that's exactly why they should be at the bottom :)

The bottom of the page stays bottom even if the class evolves and further members (variables, classes) get added at the top (which they are, since we _all_ agree variables should be placed at the top).
If public methods go in the top, the newly added member variables/classes will bump them down. 
This results in the public stuff we want to be easily reachable be now in the **middle** (and we cannot simply skip all the variables), which is sad for all of us.

Makes sense?
Jenkins retest this please.

Thanks @jkff !
- yes, I had moved delimiter to separator because of the name of the method `findSeparatorBounds()`, as soon as there is only one name, it's fine for me.
- for the `isSelfOverlaping()` implementation: it is more compact and maintainable but a little less performant :) (if we mesure complexity using number of comparison of bytes the new implementation will always do 1+2+ ...+n comparison if overlaps is n bytes or n = length -1 if no-overlap) but it is not important as this method will be run only once per text file, I agree maintainability is more important than performance in that case, just kidding :)

R: @aviemzur 
R:@amitsela 
CC: @iemejia 
CC: @peihe

This is a work in progress: I'm working to fix the failing tests.

I have some questions for you guys:
1. Is is better to rename package with `spark2` instead of `spark` ?
2. I introduced a complete new runner as I was not able to run on both Spark 1.x and Spark 2.x with the same runner (the API changed). I think it's better to have two runners instead only to upgrade the existing one.
3. Should I rename `spark` as `spark1` ?

NB: this PR superseded #3739
retest this please

I checked out this PR and looked at the diff between `spark` and `spark2` directories - it is tiny, only 189 lines of diff (compared to 24371 lines total in spark2/). There has to be a better way to do this than copy-paste of 99.2% of the code. Can you extract a common module, e.g. `runners/spark-common`, and have `spark` and `spark2` have minimal hooks on top of the common module?

Like I mentioned in #3739 the main difference (that affects compilation) is switching `Iterable`s with `Iterator`s in Spark's various functions, e.g., when extending `SparkGroupAlsoByWindowViaOutputBufferFn` implements `FlatMapFunction` or when applying to/from Pair (KV).
I agree with @jkff that we don't need a copy/paste of the runner module.

I guess we should try to use a common parent module (`spark-runner-common` ?) and have two sub-modules `spark-runner1` and `spark-runner2` each re-implementing ~20 files (maybe less).

Changes Unknown when pulling **77d486a7d451efdbb7dd00f1389464102baaa11b on peihe:jstorm-runner-9** into ** on apache:jstorm-runner**.
I normally work on Spark, but I'm happy to take a look and then we can find one of regular BEAM folks together :)

So it looks like Jenkins didn't get a chance to run the Python tests because of an unrelated failure (https://builds.apache.org/job/beam_PreCommit_Java_MavenInstall/14208/org.apache.beam$beam-sdks-python/console ).
Lets see if the Jenkins here also listens to: Jenkins retest this please.

This looks reasonable to me (e.g. LGTM pending jenkins), the one thing that I would consider is if it would make make sense to add flake8 to the pylint script run during commit so we don't regress.

Let's see what @robertwb thinks?

I also agree that such duplication of the code is dangerous and could lead to problems in the future.

IIRC the plan was we would use the same runner for both Spark 1.6.x and Spark 2.x utilizing something like `SPeL` (or other methods of reflection) to bridge the gaps where the API was broken. Instead of having to maintain two separate runners.

An example for where we do something like this today is `KafkaIO` - where we support multiple versions with conflicting APIs. we detect the version by finding specific method signatures using `SPeL` and call the correct one, abstracting this from away from `KafkaIO` using a class called `ConsumerSPeL`

Couldn't we create such a facade for the methods which interact with the APIs in Spark which have breaking changes between 1.6.x and 2.x?

Say the original method was part of the `RDD` class, and its signature is `foo(Iterator i)` vs `foo(Iterable i)`.
Can we create a class `RDDFacade` that wraps an RDD and has method `foo(Iterable i)` which translates from `Iterable` to `Iterator` depending on the signature of the method on the delegate `RDD` instance at runtime?

Guys, don't get me wrong: my intention is not to have two duplicated runners. The first target is to have an unique runner for both Spark 1.x and Spark 2.x, and if I fail to do it, I will introduce a `spark-common`.
I pushed the PR to have more visibility to the users (as asked on the mailing list).
So, I agree with all your comments, and I will move forward as @aviemzur suggested first.
Stay tuned ;)

Additional R: @kennknowles 

Note that `@SideInput` parameters are not in scope for this PR. My plan is:
1) Explicit wiring, but access via .get() - in DoFn: this PR and followup PRs after Dataflow worker changes
2) Same for CombineFn
3) Support for `@SideInput` fields and parameters for automatic wiring
4) somewhere in parallel with the above: simplification of APIs that used to require wiring but now wouldn't (e.g. deprecating CombineWithContext, DynamicDestinations.getSideInputs() etc)

Just a minor comment. The Histogram in JStorm keeps a reservoir with fixed records. It means the values of Histogram snapshot is not very accurate to calculate the sum and count of distribution metrics. If we didn't have a better solution now, I think it is OK to leave a TODO here for further improvement.
